questions.question: What is the primary purpose of AWS Edge Locations?
options: Running EC2 instances closer to users
Caching content and serving it with low latency to users globally
Managing IAM permissions at the edge
questions.explanation: Edge Locations are AWS's globally distributed network of servers (400+) designed primarily for caching content closer to users via CloudFront, reducing latency significantly.

questions.question: Which AWS services operate at Edge Locations? (Select ALL that apply)
questions.explanation: CloudFront (CDN), Route 53 (DNS), and Lambda@Edge run at edge locations. EC2 and RDS run in regional data centers, not at edge locations.

questions.question: AWS has more Edge Locations than Availability Zones.
questions.explanation: AWS has 400+ Edge Locations compared to 100+ Availability Zones. This extensive edge network enables low-latency content delivery to users worldwide.

questions.question: Match each capability with where it runs:
questions.explanation: Content caching and Lambda@Edge run at Edge Locations. Full compute (EC2) and databases (DynamoDB) run in Regions only.

questions.question: When should you use CloudFront Functions instead of Lambda@Edge?
options: When you need to make network calls to external services
When you need simple, fast transformations with sub-millisecond execution
When you need access to the request body
When you need up to 30 seconds of execution time
questions.explanation: CloudFront Functions are ideal for simple, lightweight operations (URL rewrites, header manipulation) with sub-millisecond execution and lower cost. Lambda@Edge is for complex logic requiring network access or longer execution.

questions.question: What does this command do?
options: Creates an S3 bucket named pettracker-images
Creates a CloudFront distribution with S3 as the origin
Uploads index.html to an existing CloudFront distribution
Lists all CloudFront distributions in the account
questions.explanation: This creates a CloudFront distribution using the S3 bucket as the origin. Content from pettracker-images.s3.amazonaws.com will be cached at edge locations globally.
